content: The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund and addresses various issues such as affordability, discrimination, civil rights violations, public participation, data collection, technical assistance to rural areas, sewage disposal system improvement, state water pollution control funds, and drinking water grant programs. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund under SEC. 9512 of the Internal Revenue Code to address issues related to water affordability, transparency, equity, and reliability. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States, known as the 'Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund'. The Trust Fund receives appropriations from Federal revenues and is limited to $34,850,000,000 per fiscal year. Amounts in the Trust Fund are available for specified purposes without further appropriation or fiscal year limitation. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States, limited to $34,850,000,000 per fiscal year. Amounts in the Trust Fund are available for specified purposes without further appropriation or fiscal year limitation. Chapter 98 of the Code is amended by inserting a new item after section 9511. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States. Section 952 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to define 'subpart F income' for controlled foreign corporations. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will allocate funds for specified purposes. The Environmental Protection Agency allocates funds from the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund for clean water programs and safe drinking water funding. The Environmental Protection Agency allocates funds from the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund for clean water programs and safe drinking water funding. Funds are distributed as follows: 44.5 percent for capitalization grants under section 1452 of the Safe Drinking Water Act, and 3 percent for grants under section 1465 of the Act. REPORT ON AFFORDABILITY, DISCRIMINATION, CIVIL RIGHTS VIOLATIONS, PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN REGIONALIZATION, AND DATA COLLECTION. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct a study on water and sewer services, focusing on water affordability nationwide, rates, increases, disconnections, and funding effectiveness. Additionally, the study will address discrimination and civil rights issues in collaboration with the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will study discriminatory practices and violations by water and sewer service providers receiving Federal assistance under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The study will also evaluate public participation in regionalizing public water systems and sewer services. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will collect data on people living without water or sewer services, water service disconnections, and disparate effects based on race, gender, or socioeconomic status. A report with study results and recommendations for utility companies will be submitted to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Environmental Protection Agency will collect data on people without water or sewer services, water service disconnections, and effects based on race, gender, or socioeconomic status. A report with recommendations for utility companies will be submitted to Congress. Technical assistance will be provided to rural, small municipalities, and tribal governments. Section 104(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to make grants to nonprofit organizations for providing technical assistance to rural and small municipalities and tribal governments in planning, development, and financing of eligible projects. This includes assistance for publicly owned treatment works and decentralized wastewater treatment systems. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance to rural and small municipalities, tribal governments, and municipalities meeting affordability criteria. This assistance includes planning, design, construction, and operation of treatment works and wastewater systems. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to establish a grant program for repairing, replacing, or upgrading residential onsite sewage disposal systems. SEC. 6 addresses state water pollution control revolving funds. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include new requirements for state financial assistance and the application of section 513 to construction projects funded by state water pollution control revolving funds. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow assistance for purchasing treatment works and canceling management contracts. Additionally, states can now use up to 50% of capitalization grants for subsidization. The State can use capitalization grants for additional subsidization under this title for a fiscal year. The State can utilize revolving loan funds under the Safe Drinking Water Act. Section 1452 of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow the use of funds for purchasing privately owned community water systems or canceling contracts for operation or management. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 people, not owned or managed by any other system, to receive assistance. Subsection changes include increasing assistance to 50%, providing guidance for affordable and reliable water services, and protections for households facing disconnection. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to provide assistance to public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 people. Assistance includes grants for replacing lead service lines with lead-free ones to prevent service disconnection due to unpaid water charges and ensure universal access to water and sewer services. SEC. 8. DRINKING WATER GRANT PROGRAMS. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to establish a grant program for local educational agencies to install, repair, or replace drinking water infrastructure and test water quality at schools. Additionally, amendments are made to provide assistance to tribal drinking water systems.
